posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked:
We are using Through Bore Encoders as DutyCycleEncoders plugged into DIO ports to report absolute position for our intake and shooter angle mechanisms. On the DutyCycleEncoder documentation, there are lines that say:

getAbsolutePosition() - getPositionOffset() will give an encoder absolute position relative to the last reset. This could potentially be negative, which needs to be accounted for.

This will not account for rollovers, and will always be just the raw absolute position.

How should we compensate for the values potentially being negative? We ran into a problem caused by this at NE UNH districts right before finals, and I had to come up with a quick janky fix. Since our intake retracts up into our robot to be horizontal, I treat that as 0 degrees, 90 degrees as straight up, and 210 degrees or so as down to the ground (to pick up notes). The problem was that our 0 degrees happened to correspond to an absolute position of 0.8 or so, so after moving the angle out, the absolute position minus the offset became negative, throwing off our PID loop and our angle reading.

How could this be compensated for elegantly? At UNH, we just took the encoder off the shaft and manually spun it until the 0 degrees was a position slightly above 0 so that within the range of motion, the absolute position would never be less than the offset.

Code is here: CRESCENDO-2024/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/intake/IntakeRotation.java at main · RambotsTeam1350/CRESCENDO-2024 · GitHub

posts.name: Bodi
posts.cooked: I would use this version DutyCycleEncoder class instead: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation It seems much nicer and the getDistance method is a one stop shop for getting an offset absolute position in the correct units without having to worry about subtracting an offset.

link_counts.title: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked:
IthcyPrince:

I would use this version DutyCycleEncoder class instead: Encoders - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

I thought this was the same one I was using? Are there multiple DutyCycleEncoder classes? I added my code to the original post.

IthcyPrince:

It seems much nicer and the getDistance method is a one stop shop for getting an offset absolute position in the correct units without having to worry about subtracting an offset.

What does the getDistance method return? If it is a distance, wouldn’t it be something like how far the encoder has travelled in total and not the absolute position it is in, which I need to determine the angle?

posts.name: Patrick Ambli
posts.cooked:
You can use the .enableContinuousInput(double minInput, double maxInput) method on the PID controller class to get the PID controller to understand the rollover point. You can read a bit more about the method here .

To make the rollover point a constant value (regardless of what the value of getPositionOffset()) you can modulo your encoder’s value by its total range. I think this will fix your problems

Hopefully that all made sense. It’s real late for me and I’m real tired.

link_counts.title: PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked:
Patrick_Ambli:

To make the rollover point a constant value (regardless of what the value of getPositionOffset()) you can modulo your encoder’s value by its total range.

Sorry if this is a really stupid question but doesn’t x % 1 always return 0 ?

posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked:
Patrick_Ambli:

You can use the .enableContinuousInput(double minInput, double maxInput) method on the PID controller class to get the PID controller to understand the rollover point. You can read a bit more about the method here .

Would this cause the PID controller to try to do a complete circle? The intake mechanism is not a complete circle motion, the minimum degrees is 0 and the maximum is 215. It can never exceed 215 degrees physically without breaking gears and snapping axles. I’m worried that when the intake is extended to maximum angle, it will try to run the angle from 215 to 360 instead of from 215 back to 0.

posts.name: Patrick Ambli
posts.cooked:
Ah indeed it would, for some reason, I was assuming your intake could only move in a range less than 180 degrees. Unfortunately (as far as I know) moving the crossover point to somewhere outside of the range of possible motion is the best that you can do. You can either do that by physically rotating the encoder (like you did) or you can do a bit of clever math to accomplish effectively the same thing.

This is how my team is handling it.

CrossoverOffet is a value that pushes the crossover point outside of the intake’s range. IntakeOffset shifts the encoder’s value so that when it’s at 0 the intake is parallel with the ground.

posts.name: Myer
posts.cooked: Thank you, this seems to make sense. For now I’m going to stick with how it is since it works and I don’t want to worry about it, but for future reference, I will use this method.
